thread.title: REVEALED: How YOUR MP voted on Article 50 last night
thread.title_full: REVEALED: How YOUR MP voted on Article 50 last night

title: REVEALED: How YOUR MP voted on Article 50 last night
text:
REVEALED: How YOUR MP voted on Article 50 last night REVEALED: How YOUR MP voted on Article 50 last night THE Article 50 bill cleared Parliament last night, finally giving Theresa May the legal authority to trigger Brexit and take Britain out of the EU. But how did YOUR MP vote on the Article 50 bill? PUBLISHED: 11:44,  58, Tue, Mar 14, 2017 
MPs voted to pass the Article 50 bill without two proposed House of Lords amendment. 
Handing the Government a majority of 48, MPs voted down an amendment designed to protected the rights of EU nationals living in Europe by 335 to 287. 
They also scrapped a second amendment which would have given Parliament a “meaningful vote” on the final Brexit deal by 331 to 286, a majority of 45. 
When the bill returned to the House of Lords last night, peers agreed to drop the second amendment by 274 votes to 118 votes - a majority of 156. Related articles When will Article 50 be triggered? When will Brexit talks start? 
They also voted to scrap the EU national amendment 274 to 118, a majority of 156. 
The Queen is expected to formally sign the bill into law, giving Theresa May the power to launch Brexit proceedings. 
The Prime Minister will give a statement at 12.30pm today, where she is expected to confirm that the royal assent has been given. 
Downing Street has confirmed that Article 50 will be triggered during the last week of March, ending speculation that Mrs May could give notice to Brussels as early as today. 
Here is a full list of how MPs voted on both amendments. GETTY Theresa May now has to legal power to trigger Article 50 First amendment
